turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: No sense in going up there! I been here for hours. He ain't here!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Oh, let me go, will you!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Now, that's crazy. It's fourteen floors!

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Had any schooling?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Yeah, a little.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: What do you do when you work?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: I used to pitch.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Baseball?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Uh-huh. Till my wing[4] went bad.

turns.speaker: ANN
turns.text: Where'd you play?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Bush leagues mostly.[5] Med. shot: To include the rest of them. They have their eyes glued on his face. ANN is very much interested.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: I went up to Miss Mitchell's house, boss. Boy, she's in a bad way.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, do you know something? She supports a mother and two kids. What do you know about that?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Did you find her?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: No. Her mother's awful worried about her. When she left the house she said she was going on a roaring drunk. Er, the girl, I mean!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Go out and find her!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Sure. Hey, but the biggest thing I didn't tell you . . .

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Hello! . . . Yeh?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Her old man was Doc Mitchell. You know, the doc that saved my mother's life and wouldn't take any money for it? You remember that? Okay, boss, I'll go and look for her.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: just called the morgue, boss. They say there's a girl there

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Shut up!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Ann! Say, why didn't yuh

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Beany!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, boss. Get a load of this.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Look!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What do they want?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: They all say they wrote the John Doe letter.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Yeah, Boss?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Take charge of him. Get him a suite at the Imperial and hire some bodyguards.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Both of 'em?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yes, both of 'em! But don't let him out of your sight.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, Boss.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Oh, quiet, quiet, quiet.  Say, tell me something did you read that speech you're gonna make tonight?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Gee whiz, Boss, you know Mr. Norton told me not to leave him, not even for a minute.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Go on, go on, go on. And we'll be at Jim's Bar up the street.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, wait a minute, Mr. Doe!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: . . . Tubby?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Help yourself.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Naw.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: I've seen guys like you go under before. Guys that never had a worry. Then they got ahold of some dough and went goofy. The first thing that happens to a guy

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, did yuh get a load of the bedroom?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, whatsa matter with a bank account, anyway?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: And let me tell you, Long John. When you become a guy with a bank account, they got you.  Yes sir, they got you!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Who's got him?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: The heelots!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: And when they get you, you got no more chance than a road-rabbit.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey. Who'd you say was gonna get him?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Hey, Doc, look. Look, Doc. Gimme that again, will yuh? Who's gonna get him?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: The heelots!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Who are they?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Listen, sucker, yuh ever been broke?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Sure. Mostly often.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: All right. You're walking alongnot a nickel in your jeansfree as the windnobody bothers youhundreds of people pass yuh by in every line of businessshoes, hats, automobiles, radio, furniture, everything. They're all nice, lovable people, and they let you alone. Is that right?

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: Ba-ll!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: I don't know how you're gonna stand it around here till after Christmas.

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: St-rike!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: I know why you're hangin' aroundyou're stuck on a girlthat's all a guy needs is to get hooked up with a woman.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Holy smoke! A half a heelot!

turns.speaker: BEANY
turns.text: There you are, Boss, just like you ordered. Symbols of the little people.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, I'll be doggoned if over forty people don't show up. 'Course none of us knew what to do, but we sure got a kick out of seeing how glad everybody was just to say hello to one another.

turns.speaker: BERT'S WIFE
turns.text: Tell him about making Sourpuss chairman, honey.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Oh, yeah. We made Sourpuss chairman and decided to call ourselves The John Doe Club. And, say, incidentally, this is my wife. Come here, honey.

turns.speaker: BERT'S WIFE
turns.text: Grubbel's here. See?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeah. That'sthat's him. Of course, you don't know Grubbel, but he's the man that everybody figured was the worst no-account in the neighborhood because he was living like a hermit and nobody'd have anything to do with him. Er, that is until Murphy, the postman told us the truth. "Why, Grubbel," he says, "he lives out of garbage cans because he won't take charity. Because it'd ruin his self-respect," he says.

turns.speaker: BERT'S WIFE
turns.text: Just like you said on the radio, Mr. Doe.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: You don't have toWhy, we're with you, Mr. Doe. We just lost our heads and acted like a mob. Why, we . . .

turns.speaker: BERT'S WIFE
turns.text: What Bert's trying to say iswellwe need you, Mr. Doe. There were a lot of us didn't believe what that man said.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: This is Sourpuss. Er, excuse me. Er, Mr. Smithers, Mr. Doe.

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: Ththat's all right. If you didn't call me Sourpuss, it wouldn't feel natural.  There are snickers from the background.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, anyway, II guess nearly everybody in the neighborhood came, except the DeLaneys. The Delaneys live in a big house with an iron fence around it and they always keep their blinds drawn, and we always figured that he was just an old miser that sat back counting his money, so why bother about inviting him? Until Grimes, the milkman spoke up and he said, "Say, you've got the Delaneys all wrong." And then he tells us about how they cancelled their milk last week, and how, when he found a note in the bottle he got kinda curious like and he sorta peeked in under the blinds and found the house empty. "If you ask me," he says, "they're starving."

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: Old man Delaney has been bringing his furniture over to my place at night, one piece at a time, and selling it.

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: And then we started to find out about a lot of other people.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeah, sure. Er, you know Grubbel, for instance.

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: Well, sir, about a dozen families got together and gave Grubbel a job watering their lawns. Isn't that wonderful? And then we found jobs for six other people and they've all gone off relief!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeh. Er, and my boss, Mr. Schwabacker made a job in his warehouse for old man Delaney

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Well, thank you for listening. Goodbye, Mr. Doe. You're a wonderful man and it strikes me you can be mighty useful walking around for a while.

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: How could he be a fake?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: It must be some kind of a gag.

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: A what?

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: A gag. A gag!

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: It makes no difference, Bertthe ideas's still good. We don't have to give up our club.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Yeah? Well, you can have it!

turns.speaker: SOURPUSS
turns.text: That man is gonna be on that roof. Don't ask me how I know. I just know. And you know it as well as I do.

turns.speaker: BERT
turns.text: Sure, sure. I'd like to believe in fairy tales, but a guy that's fake isn't gonna jump off any roof.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hey, pretty nifty, huh?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: You ain't gonna get me to stay here.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sure, you are.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: No, sir. That spot under the bridge where we slept last night's good enough for me.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Gimme mine. I ain't staying! You know we were headed for the Columbia River country before all this John Doe business came up. You remember that, don't yuh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sure. I remember . . . Say, did your ears pop coming up in the elevator? Mine did.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Aw, Long John . . . I tell youit's no good. You're gonna get used to a lotta stuff that's gonna wreck you. Why, that fifty bucks in your pocket's beginning to show up on you already. And don't pull that on me neither!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Stop worrying, Colonel. I'm gonna get my arm fixed out of this.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hey, stop worrying, Colonel. Fifty bucks ain't going to ruin me.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: I seen plenty of fellers start out with fifty bucks and wind up with a bank account!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You win, Colonel. Here's the fifty. Go on out and get rid of it.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: You bet I will! As fast as I can! Gonna get some canned goodsa fishing rod, and the rest I'm gonna give away.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I gotta figure some way out of this thing!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: The elevators are still runnin'.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Yeah, she's a heelot just like the rest of them. It's lucky you got away from her.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What was I doin' up there makin' a speech, anyway? Me? Huh?  Gee, the more I think about it the more I could . . .

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Tear down all the fences. Why, if you tore one picket off of your neighbor's fence he'd sue you!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Five thousand bucks!  I had it right in my hand!

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Jitterbugs.[9] Close shot: JOHN and the COLONEL.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeh. Say, how much money we got left?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Four bits.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Better make it doughnuts, huh?

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Yeh.

turns.speaker: COLONEL
turns.text: Join the John Doe Club.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: John Doe Club?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I trust him.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Oh, you trust him, eh? Well, that's fine. I suppose he trusts you, too?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, but it's got to be by Bone- Setter Brown.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Okay, Bone-Setter Brown goes. Here, sign it. Meanwhile, here's fifty dollars for spending money. That's fine. Beany!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Connell.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Hiyah, John.  John, I want to have a little talk with you.  What's the matterare you falling? Come here.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, I never read the speeches before I make them. I get more of a kick out of it that way.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Uh-huh. That's exactly what I thought. Beany, go on down to the office, tell Pop to give you the speech. There's a copy on my desk.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Now, that's all right, isn't it?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You betcha.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: I get mad for a lot of other guys besides myselfI get mad for a guy named Washington! And a guy named Jeffersonand Lincoln. Lighthouses, John! Lighthouses in a foggy world! You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, you bet!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Listen, palthis fifth column stuff's pretty rotten, isn't it?[11]

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah. It certainly is.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: And you'd feel like an awful sucker if you found yourself marching right in the middle of it, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You must be wrong, Mr. Connell, 'cause he's been marvelous about the John Doe Clubs.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yeah?  Say, you're sold on the John Doe idea, aren't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Sure. I don't blame you. So am I.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: All right! Now, supposing a certain unmentionable worm, whose initials are D. B., was trying to use that to shove his way into the White House. So he could put the screws on, so he could turn out the lights in those lighthouses. What would you say about that? Huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Nobody's gonna do that, Mr. Connell. They can't use the John Doe Clubs for politics. That's the main idea.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Is that so? Then what's a big political boss like Hammett doing in town? And a labor leader like Bennett? And a lot of other big shots who are up at D. B.'s house right now? Wolves, John, wolves waiting to cut up the John Does!  Wait till you get a gander at that speech you're gonna make tonight!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: You're all wet. Miss Mitchell writes those speeches and nobody can make her write that kind of stuff.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: They can't, huh?  Who do you think writes 'em? My Aunt Emma? I know she writes them.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Don't write 'em? Why, that gold- grabbin' dame would double-cross her own mother for a handful of Chinese yen!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Shut up! If you weren't drunk I'd

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Go down to the office and arrange for some radio time.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Why, D. B., you're not going to fall for

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: I want it as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Okay. I just came in to get warm, myself. Come on, let's go.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Well, I don't get it.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Huh? Get what?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Look, D. B. I'm supposed to know my way around. This John Doe movement costs you a fortune. This convention's gonna cost plenty.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Well, I'm stuck with two and twobut I'm a sucker if I can make four out of it.  Where do you come in?

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Whyuh

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: I see. I'd better stick to running the paper, huh?

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: I think maybe you'd better. And ConnellI'd like to have the John Doe contract, all the receipts for the money we have advanced him and the letter Miss Mitchell wrote, for which I gave her a thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Yes. Sure.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Only one thing to do, Hank. Drop the whole business quickly.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Run a story. Say John Doe was in here, and is sorry he wrote the letter and

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: That's right. You got it! Sure! He came in here and I made him change his mind. "Bulletin editor saves John Doe's life." Why, it's perfect. I'll have Ned write it up.  Oh, Ned!

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Miss Mitchell, do me a favor, will you? Go on out and get married and have a lot o' babiesbut stay out o' newspaper business!

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Better get that story in, Hank, it's getting late.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: If you ask me, Hank, you're playing around with dynamite.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: No, no, no, the gal's right. We can't let the Chronicle get the laugh on us! We've got to produce a John Doe now.  Amateur journalism, huh!  I'll show those guys.

turns.speaker: POP
turns.text: Show me an American who can keep his mouth shut andI'll eat him.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Okay, Beany, bring 'em in one at a time.  Wipe to: Montage: Half a dozen different types of hoboes appearand in each instance ANN shakes her head, negatively.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Did you write that letter to Miss Mitchell?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: No, I didn't.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What are you doing up here then?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Well, the paper said there were some jobs around loose. Thought there might be one left over.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: How about family? Got any family?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: Oh, just traveling through, huh?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Yeah. Me and a friend of mine. He's outside.

turns.speaker: CONNELL
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: TALL CHAP
turns.text: Willoughby. John Willoughby, Long John Willoughby they called me in baseball.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Look, Mr. Norton, I think you've got a lot of nerve having those people hold us here.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: There's nobody holding you here, Mr. Doe.  It's only natural that people

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, if there's nobody holding us here, let's get going. Incidentally, my name isn't Doe. It's Willoughby.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Why, certainly. With your ability to influence people, it might grow into a glorious movement.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Say, let's get something straight here. I don't want any part of this thing. If you've got an idea I'm going around lecturing to people, why you're crazy! Baseball's my racket, and I'm sticking to it. Come on, Colonel, let's get out of here.

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Is there anything wrong?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, no. Nothing's wrong. Everything's fine!  So there's gonna be a new order of things, huh? Everybody's gonna cut himself a nice, fat slice of the John Does, eh?  You forgot one detail, Mr. Big Shotyou forgot me, the prize stooge of the world. Why, if you or anybody else thinks he's gonna use the John Doe clubs for his own rotten purpose, he's gonna have to do it over my dead body!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Now, hold on a minute, young man! Hold on! That's rather big talk! I started the John Doe clubs with my money and I'll decide whether or not they're being properly used!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No you won't! You're through deciding anything!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's a lie!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: It's not a lie! Nickels and dimes! To stuff into their own pockets! You can read all about it in the newspapers there!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's a lie! Listendon't believe what he says . . .

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Let go of me!  This man had no intention of jumping off of the top of a building! He was paid to say so!  Do you deny that?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: That's got nothing to do with it!

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Were you paid for itor weren't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yes! I was paid! But the

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: And what about the suicide note? You didn't write that, either!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What difference does that make?

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Did you write itor didn't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: No, I didn't write it, but

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: Ah, you bet your life you didn't! You look in your papers, ladies and gentlemen, and you'll find Miss Mitchell's signed confession that she was the one that wrote it!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Listen, folks, it's a fact that I didn't write the letter, but this whole thing started

turns.speaker: D. B.
turns.text: There! You see? He admits it! You're a fake, John Doe! And for what you've done to all these good peoplethey ought to run you out of the countryand I hope they do it!

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: It's good to see you. Sit down.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: It's for Ann . . .

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: Oh, how nice! Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Flowers.

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: I'm terribly sorry she isn't here.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: She isn't?

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: No, she just left. I'm surprised you didn't run into her. She went over to Mr. Norton's house.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: Did you want to see her about something important?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah. I, uh, well . . . No. It'll wait.  Say, he's a nice man, isn't he? Mr. Norton, I mean. He's, er, he's done an awful lot for the

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, I guess I'll see her at the convention later.

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: Yes, of course. I'll see that she gets the flowers.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Thanks. Good night, Mrs. Mitchell.

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: Good night, John.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Oh, yeah. That's what I mean. See? It was easy as all that, huh?

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, but look, Mrs. Mitchell, you know I love Ann and it's gonna be awfully hard for me to say it because, well, you know, she's so wonderful, and, well, the best I ever was was a bush-league pitcher.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: I bet you he'd know how to say it all right. And me, I get up to it and around it and in back of it, but, but I never get right to it. Do you know what I mean? So the only chance I've got is, well, if somebody could kinda give her a warning sort of, sorta prepare her for the shock!

turns.speaker: MRS. MITCHELL
turns.text: You mean you'd like me to do it, huh?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, I was thinking thatYeah, you know, sort of break the ice.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Pretty good?  Say, I was just about ready for the major leagues when I chipped a bone in my elbow. I got it pitchin' a nineteen-inning game!

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Nineteen!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yep. There was a major league scout there watching me, too. And he came down after the game with a contract. Do you know what?  I couldn't life my arm to sign it. But I'll be okay again as soon as I get it fixed up.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: What do you mean, too bad?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Huh? Oh, that you'll never be able to play again.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Well, what are you talking about? I just told you I was gonna get a

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, you know how they are in baseballif a guy's mixed up in a racket

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Racket? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, I was just thinking about this John Doe business. Why, as soon as it comes out it's all a fake, you'll be washed up in baseball, won't you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Y-yeah. Gee, doggone it, I never thought about that. Gosh!

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: And another thing, what about all the kids in the country, the kids that idolize ball players? What are they gonna think about you?  Close shot: Of the COLONEL. He has dropped his gloveflopped into a chairand has taken out his ocarina.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: I know one way you can do it.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, when you get up on the radio, all you have to do is say the whole thing's a frame-up. Make you a hero sure as you're born!

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah, but how am I gonna get my arm fixed?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Well, that's a cinch. I know somebody that'll give you five thousand dollars just to get up on the radio and tell the truth.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Say, who's putting up this dough?

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Feller runs the Chronicle .  Here's the speech you makeand it's all written out for you.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Have you got the speech I gave you?

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MIKE
turns.text: Now, look. I'll give this money to the Colonel just as soon as you get started. We'll have a car waiting at the side entrance for you.

turns.speaker: JOHN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Spencer of the Chronicle .

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Hold him.  Yes, Mrs. Brewster, I'm listening.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Yes, Spencer. Who? The Governor? Well, what about me? it's my building he's jumping off of! And I'm up for re-election, too!

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Shh!

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: What are you doing? Get Connell at the Bulletin !  Why, he's liable to go right past my window,  What was that?!

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Out the window! Something just flew by!

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: I didn't see anything.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Well, don't stand there, you idiot. Go and look. Open the window. Oh, why did he have to pick on my building?

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Is there a crowd in the street?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: Then he may be caught on a ledge! Look again!

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: I think it must have been a sea- gull.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: A sea-gull? What's a sea-gull doing around the city hall? That's a bad omen, isn't it?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Oh, n-no, sir. The sea-gull is a lovely bird.

turns.speaker: MAYOR
turns.text: I-it's all right, Mrs. Brewster. It was just a sea-gull.  Er. nothing's happened yet! No, I'm watching. Don't worry. Ju-just leave it all to me!

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Hello, guys.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Hello, Roper. Glad you could join us.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: They're not usually graduate students.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: SWAT wants to go in.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: What's the rush? They haven't killed anybody yet this week?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: No -- you can't do that.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: You got 7 hostages in there, 1 of them's wounded -- We don't know how bad it is -- The guy ripped the phone out -- SWAT said he's got a gun to the head of a female hostage. If SWAT makes entry now, you're gonna lose 1 hostage, maybe 2. I gotta go in. Maybe I can see what's going on in there.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: He's never offed anybody. His rap doesn't show any violence.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Not that we know of.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: We don't know how much time we have. If I can get in to talk to him -- maybe we won't lose anyone.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Maybe we can get a throw phone in there.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Floor seats.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: You're my hero.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Dinner's on you.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Deal.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Mind if we make a stop on the way? We busted Frank Antonucci on possession. He gave us a lead on that Polk Street jewelry heist.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: "Phoney Frank"? Don't waste your time. He'd tell you his granny was in on the Kennedy assassination if he could dodge a collar.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: I still gotta do it. Wasting time is half my job.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Yeah, okay.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: This SWAT guy might be a good idea. He may be able to take a little pressure off you. I worry about you.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: You worried about me, too? The chief's worried about me. Solis is worried about me. Maybe you guys should start some kind of organization.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Speaking of which. I saw you talking to Ronnie this morning. Why can't you get it back together with her. You've gotta be out of your mind not to get with that one.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: It's not me. It's her. She's going out with this baseball player -- Greg Barnett.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: No shit! He's good!

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Fuck him. He swings at anything in the dirt. I could strike him out.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Don't give up on her. You're getting to the age when you ought to be thinking about these things.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Where's the stereo?

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Fuck the stereo. What's that smell?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Come on. Just get in. We gotta go.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Apartment 306.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: You want me to go up with you?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Nah, It probably won't turn up anything. I'm just gonna talk to him.

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: Good. I don't want to be late.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: What's the line?

turns.speaker: ROPER
turns.text: It was Warriors plus 6 this morning.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: I'll take half of your action.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Who is it?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: It's Lieutenant Sam Baffert from the San Francisco Police Department.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: What happened? Is there a problem?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: May I come in? I would just like to ask you a couple of questions.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Duke Ellington. "Things Ain't What They Used To Be", recorded July 30, 1945.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Yeah... Yeah... Now I can hear it.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Where did you find an old recording like that?

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Used record shop down on Turk Street. I was in there looking for some Robert Johnson.  Memories... Memory Lane or something...

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: I've got to stop in there... Mr. Korda, do you know Frank Antonucci?

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: You mean Frank who owns the bakery down the street?

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: Could I please have a little water?

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Perhaps for his own reasons he entangled me in this... situation.

turns.speaker: BAFFERT
turns.text: This cousin of yours... What's his name?

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Clarence Teal.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: You told Antonucci that shit came from me.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: So that we could get the best price. He's got respect for you. He's gonna try to lowball me, Mike.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: You fucking idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mike. I never heard of LaMarra flipping on anyone before. He said he had the cops paid off. Antonucci never flipped on anyone before. He had the cops paid off.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Not the fucking cop that showed up at my door!

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: What happened, Mike.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: You don't want to know.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: God damn it! I still needed to case that fucking store. It's too risky to show my face now.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I got a couple thousand bucks. You could leave town.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Leave town? They're going to know me in fucking Des Moines now!...  They got over ten million in jewels in that place. That's freedom, man. I could go anywhere I want.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: You gotta do this for me. I'm in here because of you.

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Man, what's this about? Ya know, you were robbing a store. It wasn't personal. It was his job.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Fuck you! You know what he did to me?!...

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Don't make do it, Mike.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Are you going to turn on me too? Who helped you when you were strung out? Who gave you money? Who bailed you out of jail?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: I won't get away with it.

turns.speaker: KORDA
turns.text: Nobody knows who you are. Make it look like a robbery.

turns.speaker: MCCALL
turns.text: I... I'm Kevin. I 'm here to help you, D... Dave.

turns.speaker: DAVE
turns.text: You can't help me, man.
